paragraphs: In this paper, I show that persons reach unanimous opinions even when they have different initial opinions and different social influences in social influence networks. Friedkin and Johnsen introduced a model of social influence networks, and identified conditions for initially diverse opinions to converge. However, they did not examine conditions of "unanimous" convergence. Hence, I provide sufficient conditions of such unanimous consensus by focusing on three typical but conflicting social influences: the equal influence, the influence of the lowest opinion, and no influence. I show that unanimous opinions occur even when persons have antagonistic social influences such as the equal influence and the influence of the lowest opinion. I also demonstrate that the most cooperative type is the equal influence, but the most central type is the no influence.

Clearly, they will agree with each other and hence accept the final unanimous opinions without any objections. If we can specify conditions of such unanimous opinion formation, it may enable us to solve social conflicts such as racial conflicts.

The process of opinion formation is modeled by , but they do not focus on unanimous opinion formation. They study how people change opinions when they change opinions repetitively in social influence networks. Although they clarify the general condition for opinions to converge, they treat unanimous convergence as a special case of convergence and hence only give some examples. Note that if we do not examine the process of unanimous opinion formation in itself, we will fail to capture what consensus formation is. This is because the process is the extreme case of successful consensus formation.

paragraphs: In this paper, I answer the question of how persons reach unanimous opinions when they have different initial opinions and have one of the following social influences: the equal influence (the utilitarian influence), the influence of the lowest opinion (the maximin influence), or no influence.
? The utilitarian influence means the equal influence of others' opinions. A person changes her opinion to the average of opinions of all the members since she treats them equally.
? The maximin influence means the influence of the lowest opinion.
A person changes her opinion to the lowest opinion of the members because she sympathizes with it.
? The no influence means sticking to her own opinion and neglecting others' opinions. She never changes her opinion.

I focus on these types because they represent typical and conflicting social influences. For example, the utilitarian influence and the maximin influence indicate antagonistic public policies. While the utilitarian influence suggests egalitarian policies such as equal taxation and equal redistribution, the maximin influence supports welfare policies such as progressive taxation and weighted redistribution. Besides, the no influence contrasts well with these two types in that it has no social influences. In the history of social theory, the utilitarian influence was proposed by , the maximin influence was advocated by , and the no influence was defended by I organize this paper as follows. In Section 2,1 will develop a model of unanimous opinion formation by modifying Friedkin and Johnsen's model. In Section 3, I will derive sufficient conditions of reaching unanimous opinions. In the last section, I will summarize my argument and provide its substantive implications. I put all proofs in Appendix. I provide only sufficient conditions of unanimous convergence because its necessary and sufficient condition has already been given mathematically for finite Markov chains (see ).

paragraphs: I show that, even though persons have diverse initial opinions, some combinations of social influences lead to unanimous opinions (either unconditional or conditional), but some cannot. I test all possible Downloaded by [Auckland University of Technology] at 18:04 01 November 2015 combinations of the three social influences, and provide three theorems. I summarize these results in the following (symmetric) table. While Theorem l(i) means democratic consensus formation, Theorem l(ii) and 2(i) represent that in welfare states. Theorem 2(ii) and 2(iii) express decisions in the monarchy or autocracy. THEOREM 1 (Unanimity from single influence) (i) If all players have the utilitarian influence, players attain unanimous opinions as the average of the initial opinions whatever the initial opinions are.
(ii) If all players have the maximin influence, players attain unanimous opinions as the lowest initial opinion whatever the initial opinions are.
(iii) If all players have the no influence, players cannot attain unanimous opinions.

THEOREM 2 (Unanimity from two influences) (i) Suppose that some players have the utilitarian influence and the rest have the maximin influence. Then, players attain unanimous opinions as the lowest initial opinions whatever the initial opinions are.

(ii) Suppose that some players have the utilitarian influence and the rest have the no influence, (a) If one player has the no influence and the rest have the utilitarian influence, players attain unanimous opinions as the initial opinion of the player having the no influence whatever the initial opinions are. (b) If two or more players have the no influence, players cannot attain unanimous opinions.

paragraphs: We can easily generalize these results as follows. To change opinions, players used convex combinations, and had no exogenous effects (Assumption 2). Such opinion changes were repeated infinitely (Assumption 3). (iii) Results: I obtained the following results. They are generalized to wider types of social influences (Corollary). Unanimity results from the utilitarian influence or the maximin influence, but does not from the no influence (Theorem 1). Unanimity results from the combination of the utilitarian influence and the maximin influence, and also results from the combination of the utilitarian influence and the no influence. But the combination of the maximin influence and the no influence results only in conditional unanimity (Theorem 2). If all the three social influences are combined, conditional unanimity results (Theorem 3).

head.text: (i) Unanimous opinions from various social influences: The results

paragraphs: show that persons can reach unanimous opinions if they keep changing opinions. This holds true even when people have antagonistic social influences, especially the utilitarian and the maximin influences. So far they are regarded as antagonistic (see , but the utilitarian influence gives way to the maximin influence when combined.

(ii) Cooperative type: In addition, suggests that the utilitarian influence is the most cooperative, and the no influence is the least cooperative. The utilitarian influence always results in unconditional unanimity, yet the no influence sometimes yields conditional unanimity or nonunanimity. This is because the utilitarian influence can give way to other social influences (by weighting all the members), but the no influence cannot (since it weights only itself). (iii) Central type: However, if we pay attention to the final unanimous opinions in the table, we should note that the utilitarian influence is the least central and the no influence is the most central. While the utilitarian influence cannot realize its opinion (i.e., the average) as the final unanimous opinions when it meets other influences, the no influence always realizes its opinion as the final unanimous opinions, if any. This happens because the utilitarian influence always gives way to other influences, yet the no influence never does so.
